form.definition: noun J or j is the tenth letter in the English alphabet.
verb If you jab someone or something, you poke or push them with something sharp or pointed. I accidentally jabbed myself with a pin. He jabbed me in the ribs with his elbow.
verb If you jabber, you talk quickly in a way that is not clear or easy to understand. Wipe your tears and stop jabberingnow, tell me what happened.
noun The jabiru is the only stork that is native to Australia.[qr

dictionary.entry:
jackdZAk
noun A jack is a mechanical device used to raise heavy objects, such as a car, off the ground.
noun A jack is a playing card valued lower than the queen but higher than the ten. Another word for this is knave.
noun In the game of lawn bowls, a jack is the small white ball used as a mark for the players to aim at.
4 jack up (a) If you jack something up, you raise or lift it, perhaps by using a jack. Evan jacked up the car and changed the flat tyre.
(b) In informal language, if you say you jack something up, you mean that you increase it. They took advantage of the surge in demand to jack up their prices.
(c) In informal language, if you say someone jacks up, you mean they refuse to do something. They become obstinate. The more we tried to persuade him, the more he jacked up.

form.definition: noun A jackeroo is someone who is learning the work that has to be done on a sheep or cattle station.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is jackaroo. ... WORD FAMILYverb jackeroo (or jackaroo) He's jackerooing in Queensland for nine months.

form.definition: noun A jacket is a short coat.
noun A jacket or dust jacket is the loose paper cover that protects a hardback book.
noun If you bake a potato in its jacket, you bake it in its skin.
noun A jackknife is a knife with a blade that folds into the handle.
verb We say a semitrailer jackknifes if the trailer swings around toward the cab like a jackknife folding.
noun A jackpot is the biggest prize you can win in a lottery or competition or on a gambling machine. The jackpot this week stands at $200 000.
hit the jackpot If you hit the jackpot, you win the main prize or you are extremely successful. One lucky entrant will hit the $50 000 jackpot. I really hit the jackpot when I found this job.
noun Jade is a dark green semiprecious stone from which jewellery and carved ornaments are made.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective jade She was wearing a pair of jade earrings.

form.definition: adjective If you are jaded, you are tired and unenthusiastic. Don't work too long hours or you'll get jaded. By the end of the week I'm always pretty jaded.

adjective If something is jagged, it has uneven, sharp or pointed edges. The sand was littered with jagged pieces of broken glass. The nail made a jagged tear in my trousers. The boat was smashed to pieces on the jagged rocks.
noun A jail is a prison, a place where people who have committed a crime are kept. She has already served more than ten years in jail. You probably won't go to jail for a first offence.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this word is gaol. ... WORD FAMILYverb jail He was jailed for life.

form.definition: noun Jam is a thick, sweet spread made by boiling fruit with sugar. What sort of jam would you like on your toaststrawberry or plum?
verb If a machine or parts of something that are meant to move jam, they become stuck. The window has jammedI can't close it. The photocopier has jammed again.
verb If you jam something into a place, you crush or force it into a tight space. You won't be able to open the drawer if you jam any more papers into it.

verb If you jam something somewhere, you push it there with force. I jammed my foot on the brake when I saw the child run onto the road. His suitcase was bulging so he had to jam down the lid to get it shut.

noun A jam is a situation where a lot of people or vehicles are crowded closely together so that it is difficult to move. As the crowds gathered, the mother warned the children not to get separated from her in the jam. We got stuck in a traffic jam on the way to the airport.
noun In informal language, if you say you're in a jam, you mean that you're in a difficult situation. I'm in a jam at the momentI just don't have enough money to pay my rent.
noun A jamb is the vertical side piece of a doorway or window frame.
abbreviation for January.
verb Metal objects jangle when they strike together and make a clanking sound. A bunch of keys jangled at his waist as he hurried up the hallway. He jangled the coins in his pocket as he spoke.
noun January is the first month of the year.
adjective If someone or something comes from Japan, you describe them as Japanese.
noun Japanese is the language of Japan.
noun A jar is a glass or pottery container which has a wide mouth and a lid. It is used to store things. Dozens of jars lined the pantry shelves. I must remember to buy another jar of honey.
verb If something jars, it creates an unpleasant harsh effect that upsets you. The loud music jarred on my nerves. That combination of colours is really jarring.
verb If you jar something, you give it a rough shake or shock. I jarred my ankle jumping down from the ladder. The passengers were jarred from their sleep as the bus crashed to a stop.

noun Jargon is language that contains special phrases and technical words and is used by people in a particular profession or group. Explain it to me simplyI don't understand computer jargon. ...medical jargon. ...legal jargon.
noun A jarrah is a large tree that grows in western Australia. It has beautiful dark red-brown wood.
noun Jaundice is a medical symptom in which your skin and the whites of your eyes turn yellow. It is usually caused by liver failure.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective jaundiced The patient is severely jaundiced.

form.definition: noun A jaunt is a short trip that you make for pleasure. We took a jaunt up the mountains to enjoy the spectacular scenery. A jaunt in the boat sounds like a nice idea.
adjective If someone is jaunty, they are cheerful, confident and outgoing. She gave us a jaunty wave as she passed. I haven't been feeling very jaunty since I split up with my boyfriend.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb jauntily

form.definition: noun A javelin is a spear that is thrown by hand. Athletes compete to see who can throw a javelin the greatest distance.
noun Your jaws are the two bones that form the framework of your mouth. You have an upper jaw and a lower jaw. Your teeth are set in your jaws.
jaws You often refer to the whole mouth of an animal as its jaws. The lion held the prey in its jaws. The crocodile snapped its jaws shut.
verb If you jaywalk, you walk in a roadway without taking notice of the road rules.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jaywalker

form.definition: noun Jazz is a type of popular music with strong rhythms.

jazz up In informal language, if you say you jazz something up, you mean that you make it more lively, exciting or colourful. I bought some bright curtains to jazz up the flat. ... WORD FAMILYadjective jazz There's a jazz band playing at the pub tonight.adjective jazzy (jazzier, jazziest) Her jazzy outfit attracted a lot of attention.

adjective If you are jealous, you want to have something that someone else has got, and you are bitter and unhappy that you haven't got it. She felt jealous of her sister's successful career. I've always been jealous of the attention he pays her.
adjective If you are jealous, you are anxious that someone will take away something that you have and you try to defend it. Billy's very jealous of his toyshe won't let other children play with them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jealousy (jealousies) adverb jealously The elders of the tribe jealously guarded the ancient customs.

form.definition: noun Jeans are casual trousers made from a strong fabric such as denim.[qr

dictionary.entry:
jeepdZi:p
noun A jeep is a military vehicle for driving on rough ground.

form.definition: verb If you jeer at someone who is speaking or performing, you shout insults at them. The crowd jeered and booed when foul play started.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jeer She ignored the jeers and finished her speech.

form.definition: noun Jelly is a soft food made from fruit juice, sugar and water. It contains gelatine, which causes it to set into a solid elastic substance that wobbles when it's moved. It is usually used as a dessert food.[qr

dictionary.entry:
jellyfish`dZEli:fIS
noun A jellyfish is an animal that lives in the sea. It has a soft, transparent body that looks like jelly. Some jellyfish are dangerous because they can sting you.
... NOTEthat jellyfish is both the singular and plural form.

form.definition: noun If something is in jeopardy, there is a risk that it could be harmed or damaged. That's a foolish thing to doyou're putting your health in jeopardy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb jeopardise (or jeopardize) The scandal could jeopardise his political career.

form.definition: noun A jerk is a sudden, sharp movement. She pulled her hand back with a jerk. The car moved along in a series of jerks.
noun If you call someone a jerk, you mean that they are a stupid person. This is an insulting word.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb jerk He jerked the tablecloth off the table.adverb jerky (jerkier, jerkiest) Try to make your movements smoother and less jerky.

form.definition: noun A jersey is a close-fitting pullover with long sleeves. Sporting teams often wear jerseys as part of their uniform.
noun A jet is a stream of liquid or gas that is forced out of a small opening. The broken main spurted jets of water into the air. He was scalded by a jet of steam.
noun A jet or jet plane is a plane powered by a jet engine.
jet engine A jet engine is an engine in which the exhaust gases are forced out in a pressurised jet.

jet lag Jet lag is the tiredness and disorientation you feel when you've travelled a long distance in a plane across several time zones. It will take a few days before you get over your jet lag and start to feel normal again.

verb If you jettison something from a ship or plane, you discard it to make the vehicle lighter. The plane jettisoned fuel before making an emergency landing. The ship's captain ordered the crew to jettison the cargo.

verb If you jettison something, you discard or abandon it. I took advantage of the move to jettison a lot of old clothes. Your plan is quite impracticalyou'd better jettison it and come up with a new idea.
noun A jetty is a long structure built out into a river or the sea and used as a landing place for boats.
noun A jewel is a precious stone, such as a diamond or ruby, which has been cut and polished. Another word for this is gem. The crown was set with dozens of jewels.
noun A jewel is a piece of jewellery made from valuable materials, such as gold or silver, and decorated with precious stones. Don't leave your jewels lying aroundthey'll get stolen.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jeweller

form.definition: noun Jewellery is adornments such as necklaces, rings, bracelets, earrings and brooches that you wear to make yourself look attractive or fashionable.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this word is jewelry.

form.definition: adjective If someone is Jewish, they follow the religion of Judaism or they belong to the ethnic group that is traditionally associated with that religion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun Jew

form.definition: noun Jibe is another spelling of gibe.
noun In informal language, a jiffy is a very short space of time. I'll be back in a jiffy. This will only take a jiffy to fix.
noun A jig is a lively folk dance.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb jig (jigs, jigged, jigging)

form.definition: verb If you jiggle something, you move it up and down or from side to side in short jerks. I'd much rather make a pot of tea than jiggle a tea bag in a cup. You have to jiggle the key in the lock to get it to turn.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jiggle

form.definition: noun A jigsaw is a narrow saw used for cutting curved shapes.
noun A jigsaw or jigsaw puzzle consists of many irregularly shaped flat pieces of cardboard or wood. When all the pieces are fitted together correctly, they make a picture.
noun A jillaroo is a female jackeroo.
verb If you jilt someone, you suddenly break off a romantic relationship with them. He was very upset when she jilted him. She was jilted at the altar on her wedding day.
verb Small metal objects jingle when they strike together and make a tinkling sound. You can hear the coins jingling in his pocket.
noun A jingle is a short, bright tune, usually with words, that is used to advertise products on television and radio. I can't get that catchy soup jingle out of my mind.

noun A jinx is someone or something that brings bad luck. Every time I go to the races with you, I loseyou seem to be a jinx for me. There must be a jinx on this machineit breaks down far more often than the others. ... WORD FAMILYverb jinx This project must be jinxedevery possible thing's gone wrong.
noun In informal language, if you say you have the jitters, you mean you feel nervous and anxious before an important event. I get the jitters every time I think about next month's exams.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective jittery I felt horribly jittery as I waited to meet her again.

form.definition: verb When you jive, you do a fast dance to a kind of popular music.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jive

form.definition: abbreviation for junior.
noun Your job is the work you do in your occupation or trade to earn a living. It is your employment. I have a part-time office job. He lost his job when the factory closed down.
noun A job is a particular piece of work or a task. When you've finished the job you're on, I want you to help Steve. I expect the children to help with the jobs around the house.
noun If it's someone's job to do something, they are responsible for doing it. You're the last to go to bed, so it's your job to put the lights out. It's not my job to make up for his mistakes.
adjective If you are jobless you don't have a job. You are unemployed. He's been looking for work for weeks but he's still jobless.
noun A jockey is someone who is trained to ride a horse in races.
noun If someone or something is jocular, they are joking. They are not serious. Something must have put her into a good moodshe's isn't usually so jocular.
noun Jodhpurs are long trousers that you can wear for riding horses. They are baggy at the top but fit tightly from below the knees to the ankles.
noun A joey is a young animal, especially a kangaroo, that is carried in its mother's pouch.
verb When you jog, you run at a steady slow pace, usually for exercise. Navin jogs at least three times a week to keep fit.
verb If you jog something, you give it a slight knock or bump. Wai-Yi asked me to jog her if she started to doze during the lecture. I managed to jog the ball into the hole.
verb If someone or something jogs your memory, they make you remember something that you'd forgotten. Give me a hint to jog my memory.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jogger

form.definition: verb If you join one thing to another or join things together, you put them together or connect them. This rope isn't long enoughwe'll need to join on another piece. The cities are joined by a railway network.
verb If things join, they come together and become united. From the lookout you can see where the two rivers join.

verb If you join someone, you meet up with them. You go aheadI'll come and join you shortly. Wendy joined us for a drink after work. b verb If you join someone in something, you take part in an activity with them. Don't be shycome and join in the conversation. Would you care to join me in a game of golf?
verb If you join an organisation, you become a member of it. I joined the company as a product manager in 1994. A good way to meet people is to join a club connected with your hobby.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun join You can hardly see the join.

form.definition: noun A joiner is someone who works in wood to make furniture and fittings for a house.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with carpenter. ... WORD FAMILYnoun joinery This table is an exceptionally fine piece of joinery.

form.definition: noun A joint is the place where two things or parts are joined. The water pipes were leaking at the joint.

noun Your joints are the parts of your body where your limbs bend, such as your elbows, wrists, knees and ankles. Grandma has just had an operation to replace her hip joint. One of the symptoms of the flu is aching joints. He suffers from arthritis in his finger joints.

noun A joint is one of the portions of meat that a butcher divides an animal's body into. It is usually a large piece, suitable for roasting. We're having a roast joint for dinner tonight. I bought a joint of lamb.
noun In informal language, you can call the building where you live or work your joint. There's a party at George's joint on the weekend. We don't have a canteen at our joint.
noun In informal language, you can call a marijuana cigarette a joint.
adjective If some-thing is described as being joint, it is shared by two or more people. I have a joint bank account with my wife. I can't take all the creditit was a joint effort.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb jointly The house is owned by the two of us jointly.

form.definition: noun A joist is a long length of wood or metal used to support a floor or ceiling.
noun A joke is something that you say or do to make people laugh. Eric is good at telling jokes. There were some excellent visual jokes in the movie.

noun A joke is a trick that you play on someone to make them believe something which is not true. He said he was calling from overseas, but it was only a joke. Let's play a joke on Sue and pretend that we've all forgotten her birthday.
noun In informal language, you call someone or something a joke if you think they are ridiculous. Our new supervisor is so inexperienced she's a joke. The government's tax policy is a joke.
no joke (a) If you say that something is no joke, you mean that it is true. It's no joke, I really am going to resign.
(b) If you say that something is no joke, you mean that it is a serious matter. It is not to be treated lightly. The situation has got out of controlit's no joke.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb joke I was only jokingit's not really true.adverb jokingly He jokingly suggest-ed that I could go there on foot.

form.definition: noun A joker is someone who likes to make jokes. Evan's a real jokerhe's never serious for a moment.
noun Each pack of playing cards contains a joker. It is a card which has no fixed value and does not belong to any of the four suits.

adjective If someone or something is jolly, they are amusing and full of fun. She's such a jolly person, she's great to be with. We all had a jolly time at the party. I'm not feeling very jolly at the momenteverything seems to be going wrong.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jollity

form.definition: verb If you jolt something, you disturb it with a sudden, rough movement. Simon jolted my elbow and I spilled my drink. I was jolted awake as the train came to a sudden halt. The tragedy jolted her out of her complacency.
verb If something jolts along, it moves along in an uneven way. The bus jolted up the hill.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jolt The car stopped with a jolt.

form.definition: verb If someone jostles, they push against other people in a crowd in a rough and rude way. People were jostling to get through the gates of the sports ground. Outside the court the crowd jostled the prisoner. I managed to jostle my way through.
verb If you jot something down, you write it quickly in note form. She jotted down the telephone message. I must jot down that appointment in my diary. I jotted his name on the back of the envelope.
noun A jotter is a book or pad of paper that you use for writing rough notes. Use a page of the jotter to make your shopping list on.
noun A joule is a unit used to measure energy or work.

noun A journal is a scientific or scholarly magazine, often published quarterly, which contains articles about research that has been done in a particular subject. The library spends a quarter of its budget on journals.
noun A journal is a record you make of daily events and your experiences. I like to keep a journal of my travels.
noun A journalist is someone who reports the news for newspapers, television or radio, or writes articles for newspapers and magazines.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun journalism

form.definition: noun A journey is a fairly long trip you make to travel from one place to another. How about coming with me on a journey to central Australia? I hope you have a safe journey. I took a book with me to read on the journey.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb journey He journeyed around Australia in his car.

form.definition: adjective If someone is jovial, they are cheerful and full of good humour. You're in a very jovial mood today. His jovial greeting as he passed made me feel better. Father Christmas is portrayed as a jovial old man in a red suit. ... WORD FAMILYnoun joviality
noun Joy is a feeling of great pleasure and happiness. She was overwhelmed with joy to see her friends again. He jumped for joy when he heard the good news.
noun A joy is something that gives you a lot of pleasure. My garden is a joy to me. Lee's just discovered the joy of horse riding. The kids are so eager that they're a joy to teach.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See rejoice. adjective joyful adverb joyfully

form.definition: abbreviation for justice of the peace.

dictionary.entry: Jr abbreviation for Junior. ...William Jenkinson, Jr.

form.definition: noun A jube is a chewy lolly.
adjective If someone is jubilant, they are very happy because of some success or triumph. She presented the medals to the jubilant winners. When I eventually worked out how to do it, I was jubilant.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jubilation

form.definition: noun A jubilee is a celebration of a special anniversarysuch as the 25th, 50th or 100thof an important event. Our school will be celebrating its silver jubilee in Marchit was founded 25 years ago.
noun Judaism is the religion and culture of the Jewish people.
noun A judge is a person authorised to hear and decide cases in a law court. The judge sentenced him to two years jail. Her bail was set by the judge at $1000.
noun A judge is a person appointed to decide the winner of a competition. The judges retired to consider their verdict. The judge's decision is final.
verb If someone judges a law case or a competition, they act as a judge. The Supreme Court judges the most serious criminal cases. It was an honour to be invited to judge the entries.

verb If you judge something, you make an estimate. She looked carefully, trying to judge the distance. It's hard to judge how long it'll take to finish. I judged that he'd be back in a couple of hours.

judging from or judging by You can say judging from or judging by when you want to give a reason for your opinion about something. Judging by the big attendance, he's a popular artist. She must be a wealthy woman, judging from the reports in the media.
noun A judgment is an official decision made in a court of law. The judgment on this case won't be given for several weeks. The magistrate is about to pass judgment on the prisoner.

noun Your judgment is your opinion, usually based on experience, about something, or the conclusion that you come to after considering a matter. I'll check all the details before I make a judgment about what to do. In our judgment, the business will never be profitable.

noun Judgment is also the ability to decide wisely. You showed good judgment in waiting as prices have now come down. We'll rely on his judgment as he's so experienced. She made a serious error of judgment in appointing him.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is judgement.

form.definition: adjective Judicial means relating to the judging of law cases. Australia's judicial system is based on the British model. There will be a judicial enquiry into the matter. The decision is subject to judicial review.

dictionary.entry: judiciousdZu:`dIS@s adjective If someone is judicious, they are wise and show good sense. They consider situations carefully before acting. Sol has always been a judicious adviser to the family. It may be judicious to seek professional advice. ... WORD FAMILYadverb judiciously I want to act judiciously and not be rushed into a decision.noun judiciousness

form.definition: noun Judo is a Japanese art of self-defence which is practised as a sport.
noun A jug is an open container for liquids. It has a handle and a wide mouth with a lip for pouring. I put the sugar bowl and milk jug on the tray.

verb When someone juggles, they keep a large number of things such as balls and plates moving continously through the air by throwing them up and catching them quickly. I begged my uncle to teach me to juggle.

verb If you juggle a lot of different activities, you manage to keep them all going by spending time on each of them in turn. I don't know how he manages to juggle his travel schedule, family life and role in the local church.

verb If someone juggles things, they adjust them to be more convenient or to deceive someone. Their financial position isn't as good as it looksthe figures have been juggled. I'll have to juggle my timetable so that I can get to the dentist tomorrow.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun juggler

form.definition: noun Juice is the liquid part that you can squeeze out of fruit, vegetables or meat. I ordered a glass of fresh orange juice.
noun In informal language, juice is fuel, especially petrol. You'd better fill the tank upyou don't want to run out of juice.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective juicy (juicier, juiciest) That was a nice juicy piece of steak.

form.definition: noun A jukebox is a machine in a place such as a cafe or pub that can play a lot of different pieces of popular music. People put coins into the machine and push buttons to choose which music it will play.
abbreviation for July.
noun July is the seventh month of the year.

noun A jumble is a situation where a lot of things are mixed up together untidily. It is a muddle. There were clothes, shoes and books lying everywherethe room was a jumble. I'm too tired to think clearlymy mind's a jumble.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb jumble She couldn't find a matching pair of socksthey were jumbled in the drawer.

form.definition: noun A jumbo is a large plane used for intercontinental flights. Jumbos need long runways to take off and land.
noun In informal language, a jumbo is an elephant.

adjective In informal language, you can call something jumbo if it's larger than usual. It's much cheaper to use the jumbo size. We decided to have a jumbo garage sale and get rid of all our unwanted stuff.
noun Jumbuck is an old-fashioned informal word for a sheep.

verb If you jump, you spring or leap. You move your whole body through the air. Ben jumped down from the garden wall. The child was jumping up and down on the bed with excitement. I tried to jump over the puddle.
verb If you jump somewhere, you move there quickly. Rosa jumped to her feet when I came into the room. Jump in and I'll give you a lift into town.
verb If you jump from fright or surprise, you move your body with a jerk. Ahmet sneaked up on me and made me jump.

verb If you jump from one thing to another, you move abruptly, missing out things in between. The program was frustratingit kept jumping from one topic to another. You can jump the next ten pages and go to the end of the chapter.

verb If something such as the temperature or a cost jumps, it increases suddenly by a big amount. The company's profits jumped to two million dollars this year from one million last year. The number of students enrolled in universities has jumped to new levels.
jump at If you jump at an opportunity, you accept it eagerly. Carina jumped at the offer of promotion. I'd jump at the chance to go to London.

jump on In informal language, if you say you jump on someone, you mean that you speak to them sharply because you don't approve of what they're doing. She jumped on him for coming inside with muddy shoes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jump I made a jump for the end of the rope. He gave a jump when his name was called.

form.definition: noun A jumper is a knitted garment that covers the top half of your body and has sleeves. It has no fasteningsyou pull it on and off over your head. Often you wear it on top of a shirt or blouse.
form.note: ... OTHER WORDSfor this are pullover and sweater.

form.definition: adjective If you are jumpy, you are so nervous or excited that you're easily startled by unexpected noises or movements. I often feel jumpy when I'm home alone at night. I've been jumpy all day waiting to hear the results.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun jumpiness

form.definition: abbreviation for June.
noun A junction is a place where roads or railway lines come together or cross each other. Turn left at the next junction. There's a complicated junction coming up.
noun A juncture is a particular point in time in a sequence of events. Ping felt it appropriate at this juncture to make the announcement. Now is not the right juncture to tell him.
noun June is the sixth month of the year.
noun A jungle is a thick forest in a tropical country. The trees are overgrown with tangled vegetation, and it is hard to walk through it.

adjective If someone is junior to someone else, they are lower in rank or status than them. Mark Horwitz is the junior partner in the firm of Green and Horwitz. As the most junior member of staff, I was expected to fetch the mail. Marisa was appointed as a junior editor.

adjective You can use Junior after someone's name if they are the younger of two people with the same name. Usually they are the son of the other person. An abbreviation of this is Jr. ...William Jenkinson, Junior.

noun In rather formal language, if you say someone is your junior, you mean they are younger than you. My two brothers are four and six years my juniors. I was pleased to be able to outrun someone so much my junior.
adjective If something is described as junior, it is for children. Sam is a member of the junior soccer club. I bought Tara a junior cricket bat.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is senior.

form.definition: noun Junk is things that have little use or value. The basement was full of junk that had collected over the years. Suddenly the printer started pouring out a lot of junk.
noun A junk is a flat-bottomed Chinese boat.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb junk We've no more use for this old table we're going to junk it.

form.definition: noun In informal language, you can call a drug addict a junkie.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this word is junky.

form.definition: noun A junta is a small group of people who rule a country, usually after a revolution. Power is in the hands of a military junta.

noun If something is within the jurisdiction of a particular authority, they have the right to make decisions about it. Appointing staff doesn't lie within my jurisdiction. Bankruptcy matters come under the jurisdiction of the Federal Court.

noun A jury is a group of people chosen to listen to the evidence given in a criminal case and decide whether the accused person is guilty or not. The jury found the accused guilty of manslaughter. Trial by jury is meant to prevent unjust treatment of individuals by those in authority. Have you ever served on a jury?
noun A jury is also a group of people who judge a competition. The chair of the jury has a casting vote.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective jury I received a summons for jury service.noun juror Jurors are not allowed to discuss the case with anyone outside the panel.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is just, they are fair. He was a wise and just ruler. That was a very just decision. It hardly seems just that he should lose all the money.

adverb If something has just happened, it happened a very short while ago. I've just heard about the accident. Adele's just finished high school. I can't believe the globe's gone againI've only just changed it. I'd just got in when the phone rang.
adverb If you just manage to do something, you nearly don't succeed in doing it. I can just reach the top shelf. I only just caught the busI had to run for it.

adverb You can use just to indicate that something is limited in some way. Don't expect too muchthey're just youngsters. This is just the beginningthere's more to come. These are just a few of the colours available. I'll just make a cup of tea.

adverb Just also means 'exactly'. The present you gave me is just what I've always wanted. Put it down just here. He looks just like his father. This one is just as good as the other. I came just at the right time.
adverb Just is also used to emphasise something. These roses are just beautiful. 'Why do you like it?' 'I just do.' Just imagine the chaos that it would cause.
just about Just about is used to indicate approximation. It's just about lunchtime. I've had just about enough of him and his complaints. 'Can you manage?' 'Just about.'
just as well If you say that it is just as well that something is the case, you mean that it is fortunate or lucky that it is so. It's just as well you know the way or we'd be lost.
just now (a) Just now means 'at this time'. Leon's in the shower just nowcan he call you back later? (b) Just now also means 'a short while ago'. Alinta called in just now to drop off some books.
noun Justice is fairness. There's no justiceI do all the work and she gets all the credit.
noun The justice of an allegation or complaint is whether it is true or reasonable. There's some justice in what she says. He protested, with some justice, about the way he'd been treated.
noun Justice is also the way criminals are tried and punished by the legal system. They wanted to see the robbers brought to justice. There has been a serious miscarriage of justice.
do justice (a) If you do someone justice, you treat them fairly. The applicants can't deny that we've done them justice.

(b) If something does you justice, it shows you to be as good as you really are. The photo doesn't really do her justiceshe's much prettier than that. Andrea was so nervous that she didn't really do herself justice in the exam.

dictionary.entry:
justice of the peace`dZV st@s @v D@ pi:s (plural form\optima0\justicesofthepeace
noun A justice of the peace is a citizen who is authorised to administer oaths and take statutory declarations and affirmations.

form.definition: verb If something justifies something, it is a reason why it is right or necessary. The urgency of the matter justified the overtime payments. In the circumstances her actions were justified. You would be justified in claiming compensation.
verb If you justify something, you try to show that it is right or necessary. I enclosed the receipts to justify my claim. How can they possibly justify using so much water during a drought?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective justifiable The expenditure was justifiable in view of the urgency.noun justifiably He was justifiably indignant about the way he'd been treated.noun justification There can be no justification for his behaviour.

form.definition: verb If something juts, it sticks out beyond something. The headland jutted into the sea. Don't trip on that rock that's jutting out of the ground.
noun Jute is a fibre that comes from a plant and is used to make rope and coarse cloth.
adjective If something is described as juvenile, it is for children or young adults. He's only 16 and will be tried in the juvenile court.
adjective If you say someone is juvenile, you mean that they behave in a childish way. His juvenile pranks really get on my nerves. Don't be so juvenilethis is a serious matter.

verb In formal language, if you say two things are juxtaposed, you mean that they are placed close together. The paintings were cleverly juxtaposed to show the contrast. In the city centre, affluence is strikingly juxtaposed with poverty.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun juxtaposition[fa[xp
